text: It also means hiring a more diverse workforce at places like @Interior and @NatlParkService. When the people working on, protecting and improving our #publiclands reflect our country‚Äôs diversity, some people get uncomfortable - but everyone else appreciates it and feels welcome.

What does that mean in practice?

- More historical sites that accurately reflect our country‚Äôs history rather than whitewashing it. - Encouraging multiple-use #publiclands that aren‚Äôt just about hiking and camping.
- Urban parks and city-accessible sites for kids to play.

Led by @RepTjCox, we held a hearing on this last week, and the author is right - access to #publiclands really is important for our health and well-being, and our #nationalparks and monuments really do need to be more diversified. https://www.washingtonpost.com/travel/2020/09/17/national-parks-travel-black/

Separation of powers and checks and balances are an acknowledgment that human beings cannot be completely trusted, especially when given power. But less societal trust isn‚Äôt a catalyst for less government; it‚Äôs a catalyst for more government. If you desire liberty, trust is key.

The idea of limited government is founded upon the belief that human beings are trustworthy. The reason our Constitution has checks and balances rather than concentrated power and commands is that we trust one another. Societies with low levels of trust turn to authoritarianism.
The erosion of trust is the erosion of liberty.

In 1993 she was nominated by Bill Clinton to be a Supreme Court Justice. She was confirmed by a 96-3 vote in the Senate. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiX1NqPWkAM-qAv.png

Throughout her life, she never wavered in her support for ratifying the Equal Rights Amendment, saying, ‚ÄúI would like to show my granddaughters that the equal citizenship stature of men and women is a fundamental human right.‚Äù #ERANow

In 1978 the House Judiciary Committee conducted hearings on the ERA deadline. The witnesses included future Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, who was then a professor at @ColumbiaLaw. She argued Congress had the authority & the ‚Äúresponsibility‚Äù to extend the ratification deadline.

In 1973 she wrote a piece for the @ABAesq Journal ‚ÄúThe Need for the Equal Rights Amendment‚Äù saying it ‚Äúlooks toward a legal system in which each person will be judged on individual merit and not on the basis of an unalterable trait of birth‚Ä¶‚Äù #ERANow 
https://www.jstor.org/stable/25726416
In 1972, RBG co-founded the @ACLU Women's Rights Project. As the director of the Project, she argued 6 gender discrimination cases before the Supreme Court between 1973 - 1976. She won 5.
RBG won in Reed v. Reed & it was the first time in American history that the court struck down a state law because it discriminated based on gender.

RBG was inspired by brilliant pioneering Black transgender attorney Pauli Murray to persuade the Warren Court to extend the 14th Amendment‚Äôs Equal Protection clause to women. In 1971 RBG credited Murray in her first Supreme Court brief in the case of Reed v. Reed.

In 1970 she co-founded the @RutgersLaw Women's Rights Law Reporter. Still published today, it was the 1st legal periodical in the U.S. to focus exclusively on women‚Äôs rights law-- paving  the way for RBG to become a leading architect of the legal fight for women's rights.

RBG, as she was called fondly by many, lived an exemplary life. Born and raised in Brooklyn, she was a proud New Yorker. She went to college in New York at @Cornell & graduated from @ColumbiaLaw tying for first in her class.

As we organize, we must also mourn hero and Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg. I stand together with Americans across the country mourning her loss. I cherished the moments I got to spend with her & she inspired me to fight for women. May she rest in power. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiX0elxX0AALJSF.jpg

Ruth Bader Ginsburg‚Äôs dying wish was that her vacancy not be filled until we have a new president‚Äî I will fight tooth & nail with my colleagues in Congress to honor her wishes. I am encouraged by how many of my Republican colleagues have committed to doing the same.

Larry has lived a remarkable life of faith, family, service, duty, honor‚Äîand fun: skiing, scuba-diving, parachuting, learning to fly a plane, gardening, playing music, travel, and more.

I'm proud to represent him, and to wish him a very happy birthday.
https://www.orangeobserver.com/photo-gallery/wwii-veteran-living-full-life-at-100

Faith has always been important to Larry, not just during the war, but also after.

He helped establish Winter Garden's Seventh-day Adventist Church, as well as others around the country.

After the war, Larry came back home and took his GED. He met his future wife, Lois, while working on a Christmas committee, and both would go on to become nurses.

They had six children (not to mention ten grandchildren and two great-grandchildren).

Larry bravely served in Italy, France, and Germany. Here is a letter written for a local newspaper by two men whose lives he helped save in Europe, an act of courage that earned him the Bronze Star. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EiXJUm7XgAAiuip.jpg

Fortunately, with the help of friendly local pastors and a considerate colonel, he managed to achieve a transfer to a medical unit attached to his anti-aircraft battalion. He travelled to Africa, then Europe.

This led to longstanding conflicts between him and his commanding officers. He had to hold strong against immense pressure‚Äîeven a threat of court martial and the death penalty.

As he said afterward, ‚ÄúI have to admit, I did a lot of praying."

Larry was born to a large family in Wisconsin and after graduating from 8th grade, dropped out of school to work on his family's farm.

In 1942, he was drafted into the U.S. Army. But, as a devout Seventh-day Adventist, he refused to take life, or to train to take one.

Please join me in wishing Mr. Larry Cheever a happy 100th birthday.

A man of faith and family who was decorated as a medic during World War II, Mr. Cheever worked as a nurse for decades, and lives in Winter Garden.
